cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
-1: Please read the comment in lines 2238 through 2243 to understand why current code is correct and this change will break a lot of things in Cinder.

The summary is that there was a time where we added a change in Cinder so we required to do an or of the 2 available options 'hostname@backend' and 'hostname@backend#pool'.

This method is not meant to look for 'hostname@backend#%' when host is of the form 'hostname@backend#pool'.

The issue you are facing should not require changing this DB method.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Thanks a lot Elvira!
I have some concerns about this patch.

First, this adds two ACLs per Security Group which is what the neutron_pg_drop was aiming to avoid.

- If we take approach (just for logging purposes), I think that this should be a series of patches that will as well remove the neutron_pg_drop. Otherwise, ovn-controller will end up expanding 2 drop rules *per port*. (**note below)

- Also, please note that we're trying to remove the neutron_pg_drop (in favor of neutron_pg_allow) because, at scale, this results in a large amount of flows that we can avoid by changing the default firewall policy at core OVN level. This patch of yours would probably defeat this purpose.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/839066 

- If a performance hit is 'allowed' for logging purposes, we can consider having these ACLs only when SG logging is enabled. This is a bit complicated as we'll need to add/delete them upon configuration changes (hopefully not often ;) 


** We should actually verify that ovn-controller will expand them twice. I'm just guessing.

neutron/common/ovn/acl.py.message: sorry, I'm being pedantic here. The previous method is called "add_acls_for_drop_xxx". Why don't we call this method "add_acls_for_drop_security_group()" (same prefix)?

It might be more beautiful but it wouldn't be a good explanation as there is no such thing as drop security groups, this function purpose is to create drop acls that are added to port groups associated to security groups.
I know we don't have a standard for naming these IDLs, but "ovn_nb" or "nb_idl "could be better in this case.

neutron/common/ovn/constants.py.message: Hold on, that will affect existing deployments. Any ACL created before updating, will have the previous values. If that's the case (please, check it), you need a migration tool here.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: The drop ACL depends on the SG, not the rules (the ACLs per rule are deleted in "_process_security_group_rule"). Shouldn't you delete this drop ACL group here?
They get deleted, because I don't create a new port group, I just add delete ACLs to the SG port group that already existed. Therefore, the pg_del in line 2286 should be enough
Let's save DB accesses: please, cache this query at the beginning of "sync_acls" instead of calling it twice here and in L275.
Why for port group? Shouldn't this be for security group ("add_drop_acl_for_security_group")?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Black is terrible for formatting function definitions and makes code much 
harder to read, please just no.

I really want to -2 this.
Here are a few examples where I think black's formatting choices makes things look worse than before.

I agree that this contributes to the consistency of code across cinder but I must admit that at some places, it makes the code really hard to read and adds syntax to places which is really not necessary. Also with the 492 comments on pep8 failure, we can clearly see that this formatting doesn't comply with pep8 guidelines. Personally it would be a downvote from my side.
Quite a few of us have voiced opinions that this change makes the code harder to read than it is currently.

While there is a lot to be said for consistency and objective code format feedback, I vote against this. I think black may be a good option for new code bases, but trying to switch over something like cinder at this point has more risk than advantage.

Though I will admit I think black makes code harder to read and uglier, so a definitely am biased.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
i dont think there is any reason to backport this on its own.
it dows not actully fix any bug so unless this is used for another change i dont think we should spend effort review and backporting this.
I'm really concerned by the "shell=True" and the usage of plain "|" in subprocess.Popen. This should be reworked in order to avoid this bad practice, imho.

Using shell can be a security risk only if your command input data comes from an untrusted source. Is 'podman ps --all' or value of SOCKET constant untrusted source? Possibly. But if an attacker is capable of changing podman's command output (eg. swapping mounted podman socket owned by root) or value of the constant in the script, then he/she does not need this script to do more harm.

But sure I can definitely use two Popens and have commands as list instead, so that security guys sleep a bit better :).

user    0m4.467s

shell=False ->

user    0m4.366s
sys     0m1.614s
Question is what's faster approach. I can do some measurements and get back

specs/zed/support-v2-cnf-heal.rst.message: Is the expression "workload resource" more appropriate?

Since `VnfcInfo` and `VnfcResourceInfo` are mixed in this spec, how about you unify them?
I think `VnfcInfo` is a variable that is actually implemented, so I think it is better to unify it to `VnfcResourceInfo`. What do you think?

Thank you for your kind explanation. I understand.
So since it was changed/clarified definition of VnfcInfo in sol002 v3.3.1, the behavior of V2 API will also change.

`VnfcInfo` and `VnfcResourceInfo` are different parameters.
Tacker stores both parameters, and this SPEC also distinguishes them.

`VnfcInfo` is defined only by SOL002.
Would you see SOL002 v3.3.1 5.5.3.23 Type: VnfcInfo?

Note that, in the v1Heal, `vnfcInstanceId` in HealVnfRequest is mapped to `VnfcResourceInfo.id`. However, vnfcInstanceId in HealVnfRequest is mapped to VnfcInfo.id according to the SOL002. The v2Heal follows the NFV standard correctly.

swift/common/middleware/slo.py.message:
What if the object was still fairly large (multiple gigs, say)? Maybe we could just do a

 close_if_possible(resp)

? Are the 499s annoying?

Alternatively, we could include a range header like bytes=-1 and tell the object server to ignore the range header if it's an SLO manifest, similar to what we do in https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/e8b654f318cfab485a772e19db33cb2fe4c3d858 -- though it gets a little annoying if we have to worry about rolling upgrades from pre-2.24.0 swift. General advice is to upgrade storage layer before proxies (in which case there isn't actually a concern), but that isn't always practical.

First, thanks for the review.

I try to simply use `close_if_possible(resp)` but that don't resolved the memory leak, that's why I use `drain_and_close(resp)` instead.

I try your suggestion to use `update_ignore_range_header` and that works fine even with `close_if_possible` (no more memory and socket leak on my preprod env) BUT this patch broke all other SLO delete tests and after an lot of try I don't find a way to fix that :-/

WIP new patch:
```
-        resp = Request.blank('', new_env).get_response(self.app)
+        # Get only one byte if object is not a SLO manifest
+        manifest_req = Request.blank('', new_env, range='bytes=0-1')
+        update_ignore_range_header(manifest_req, 'X-Static-Large-Object')
+        resp = manifest_req.get_response(self.app)
 
         if resp.is_success:
             if config_true_value(resp.headers.get('X-Static-Large-Object')):
@@ -1532,8 +1535,8 @@ class StaticLargeObject(object):
                 except ValueError:
                     raise HTTPServerError('Unable to load SLO manifest')
             else:
+                # Close GET request (prevents socket leaks)
+                close_if_possible(resp)
                 raise HTTPBadRequest('Not an SLO manifest')
```

I try to emulate `update_ignore_range_header` in `FakeSwift.__call__` without success.

swift/obj/watchers/dark_data.py.message: force record_type=object as per the proxy getter? we expect the root to sometimes return its own shard range
I looked at the code of swift/container/server.py:GET and I do not see just how it would ever return its own shard range unless the request includes 'x-backend-record-type' header.

this is way too weak - surely we should not just ignore a node that doesn't reply?

https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1925782

Per our discussion in the IRC meeting, I agreed that it's safer to obtain replies from all container servers and made a separate change to address it:
 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/792713

I think we can rebase this easily if that one merges first or vice versa.

I'm going to answer because Tim inherited this logic from my code. My reasoning was that objects are considered dark (returned as dark from get_info_1() only if all replies that are returned without error do not contain the object. Therefore, it is possible that all nodes that contain listings returned error, and all of those that returned something, returned no record, and therefore the object would be considered dark. However, I see no practical way to negate that scenario if we are to declare objects as dark in presence of any failures. The only alternative is to require that all nodes in the ring were reacheable and returned an empty record. Let me know if you think that is a better condition, of if I miss another possiblity.
I think the server can filter for us if we send an 'includes' param
ok, the code makes sense. It can return empty though.
Is it possible for account name for the shard to be different from the root?
does the age of the object get checked anywhere before it is marked as dark? what if it's in async_pending?
related to comment above about age - the object record might be misplaced or not yet in the shard, if sharding or shrinking is in progress

But the states=listing only makes it worse for us, right?

I think the answer here is not run a watcher with a permission to delete objects if your cluster is undergoing an upheaval.
I think this could be None when recursing: shard_x namespace contains object name, shard_x returns shards y, z, shard y namespace does not container object, shard_range = None

You're absolutely right.

The fix seems very simple, just continue looking for shards containing item, if any.

I think that here we should be issuing a get with 'x-backend-record-type=object', particularly if we add 'states=listing' to the original request, because the shard ranges may be pointing back to the root.

prefix is ignored by a shard range GET, so I think we'll get back the entire set of shards, then search them all for the object 😞 IDK, maybe that is the intent?

marker/end_marker is respected for shard range GET, or send 'includes=obj_name' as well as prefix
I verified that including includes=obj_name was the right thing to do. It required updating the direct client.
I wonder if we shouldn't be sending the 'states=listing' param so that we only get back shard ranged when the shards might be expected to have the object row

The "states=listing" seems like a good idea, but I do not entirely follow the implications. I'm not certain if this works correctly too: I do not see where names are converted into state numbers before _get_shard_range_rows issues a DB query. I'm going to leave this as-is for now.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Just so I'm clear, the suggestion is that instead of installing the pip and venv packages for each interpreter requested, we should use get-pip.py to install those things now?

ensure_pip_from_upstream_interpreters was never about venv installation.  If you set "ensure_pip_from_upstream = True" then the role will use the interpreters listed in "ensure_pip_from_upstream_interpreters" to run

 for i in <ensure_pip_from_upstream_interpreter>
   $i get-pip.py
 
Originally this was used with this list having "python3, python2" so that we'd install pip from upstream globally with python3 first, then python2, so that "/usr/bin/pip" was owned by python2.  (but you could specify it the other way if you wanted).  If "ensure_pip_from_upstream = False" then this argument doesn't do anything.

Hopefully nobody uses this any more.  We ditched the global upstream pip install on our images and this is the vestigial remains of our transition.

I think this stemmed from this role not handling "python3.8" and "python3.9" installed simultaneously.  Whatever we need to do to fix this, it shouldn't have to do with this argument.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message:
Hey,
Have you considered using a class for storing connection properties and using them inside the os-brick code.

It would be possible to do 
`class NvmeofConnectionProperties(dict)`

Since it would still be a dict, the probability of breaking something is small.
Thanks to the class you could add methods to convert older formats to the unified one (e.g. when building the instance). Then it could have properties so it's no longer needed to access dict values directly.

This class would be a standarized interface for connection properties and any future drivers/connectors should respect it.
Organizing the code into classes looks really good. Thanks!

We discussed this on IRC but I forgot to update the comment here.

We agreed that, while this would probably be the way to go in a new implementation, doing it in the current code would be a considerable effort, since all os-brick connectors would need to be changed, all cinder drivers, cinder API, cinder RPC, and even nova would need to be changed.

Since I really consider it to be a great suggestion (one I had considered in the past) I decided to do it at least for this specific connector, so the connection properties dictionary is converted to an instance of the new NVMeOFConnProps class so the dictionary is no longer used internally.

I would do that as well, but unfortunately one of our current code paths doesn't do that [1], so we should preserve the behavior behavior (at least for now).

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/7f747456dce8845a9e4982586729ade99d2bb14e/os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py#L577-L580
Not sure what are Python version constraints. The better tool for that would be pathlib, although glob is used everywhere here so I guess it's better to stick to one lib.
I don't see any clear benefit at the moment. It's just Pathlib is made exactly for working on paths and makes path modifications much simpler and readable.

Currently 3.8 is the oldest supported version, so using pathlib wouldn't be an issue.

In this case I'm not sure if there would be much benefit from using it, or at least I'm not seeing it.
Why not to use f-string here as well?
I believe in this case it's clearer and marginally more efficient.

host_nqn is a str as well.
Actually it is not used in the constructor.

I don't know what's host_nqn according to nvmeof protocol spec but I need to pass specific host_nqn to connect to my SDS.

Previous implementation did "nvme connect ... -q <host-nqn>" and that something I need.

At the moment it seems not implemented

 cmd = ('connect', '-a', portal.address, '-s', portal.port,
        '-t', portal.transport, '-n', target.nqn, '-Q', '128',
        '-l', '-1')
I'll update the patch to include the host_nqn support, since it is a regression not supporting it (it is currently supported).

host_nqn is not currently needed, and afaik you wouldn't need it either unless you are doing things in an unconventional way.

The Cinder driver will receive the NQN from the host that wants to connect and that's the one that should be used by the storage solution to allow access.

Here on the os-brick side the connect command will use the value of /etc/nvme/hostnqn (which is the one reported to Cinder) by default, and that's why we don't need to provide it.

Do you have a case where that behavior is not good enough?
Thx. I'm happy as long as I can pass an arbitrary host_nqn.

Thanks for re-implementing this.

The specification 
https://nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-Base-Specification-2.0b-2021.12.18-Ratified.pdf

Section 4.5
"NVMe Qualified Names (NQNs) are used to uniquely describe a host or NVM subsystem for the purposes of identification and authentication"

As I understand NQNs are for identification and authentication.
If we use hostname as host nqn then what happens if you reboot a VM on a different host?

You boot VM1 on HOST1, attach NVME1 with subsys_nqn: snqn1 and host_nqn: host1.
Then you move the VM (e.g. migration, whatever) and it lands on HOST2.
So it wants to attach NVME1 it would use subsys_nqn: snqn1 and host_nqn: host2?

In case of the SDS I'm using host_nqn is arbitrarily assigned by the SDS side. Each target has unique host_nqn. So for my case /etc/nvme/hostnqn is not much usable as I need to pass host_nqn which is fetched by cinder driver through SDS API.

I'll try to find out why it's like that.

If you do a VM migration, then Nova knows that connection information for the source and target host will be different.

So Nova asks Cinder to allow the target host access to that same volume, then moves the VM, and finally Nova asks Cinder to remove access to the volume from the source host.

That's why it's not necessary to set the host_nqn, because VMs are not moved to other locations and expected to have access to the storage.  Just imagine if that was the case and storage is FC with Zoning, the FC switches would not allow traffic to reach the target host.

I think the implementation here is broken.
Observed on real system - I got 3 portals, but only 2 got controller attribute set.

Please take a look, I hope it's readable.

  self.portals = ['p1', 'p2', 'p3']
  sysfs_portals = ['p1', 'p2', 'p3']
  ctrl_paths = ['p1', 'p2', 'p3']

  # first loop
  ctrl_portal = 'p1'
  index = sysfs_portals.index(ctrl_portal)  # index=0
  self.portals[index].controller = 'c1'  # 'p1' got 'c1'
  del sysfs_portals[index]  # remaining sysfs_portals = ['p2', 'p3']
  # second loop

You have to discover the target device before you can attach any presented volume, so this the wrong way around...

This is referring to attaching the volume using the nvme client and then discovering the device within the Linux host.

Discovery is not required to connect to an nvme subsystem.

There is nowhere in the code where an `nvme discover` is performed. If this isn't done then the `nvme connect` will not succeed, specifically in the case of an external array connecting over RDMA.
You need to have the following run (doesn't matter if it is rerun - makes no difference)  for each target portal

nvme discover -t portal.transport-a portal.address -s portal.port

From the point of view of the NVMe-oF os-brick connector, the discovery of NVMe subsystems contained in NVMe Targets is a new feature, since os-brick currently doesn't support it.

Discovery is not necessary with the current implementation because Cinder drivers are required to send the "target_nqn" in the connection information.  So why would os-brick want to do the discovery to look for the information that is already provided in the connection information?

I tested this a while back with RDMA (using the devstack patch that uses Soft-RoCE) and it worked just fine.  You can try it if with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/814193.

As far as I understand, the main problem with running glance-api under wsgi was handling of async tasks[1], but that was already resolved.

Putting WIP until I test this in integration jobs.

I hear from glance developers that glance doesn't always work well under httpd+mod_wsgi. I don't know the details, and it's possible the issues are related to large production deployments (i.e. httpd+mod_wsgi might be OK, but only in some environments).

I just want to raise this point before this patch might merge.

Downstream use of TripleO (RHOSP) is specifically the context in which I was told by a glance core that it's a "bad idea."

I'm trying to get the glance people to comment here, but I'm sort of caught in the middle.

As far as I'm aware of, there was an issue with async tasks in the past but that has been fixed by https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1888713 . Currently glance runs under uwsgi in devstack by default and it has been tested for some extent. So providing the option to use wsgi is now useful, I believe.

We might still need to continue discussion before we switch the default set up in our testing, but I personally hope we can pursue this as it helps us to deploy all services consistently. Also, as you know, this would help us implement TLS support easier in TripleO, with getting rid of tls-proxy we are forced to use now.
I'm OK knowing the original deployment model is retained as the default, and adding support for httpd+mod_wsgi is an option for deployments that wish to opt into it.

I don't really intend to make this switch in either TripleO or RHOSP atm without consulting the respective teams but just trying to implement the initial capability here so that we can use this in the future.

As long as I tested this in puppet ci it has been working and I'd think this is quite reasonable to add this capability and start testing this (would be better to limit this to specific jobs atm ?) in puppet CI considering the benefits we are expecting for this.

We can discuss futher especially when we think of implementing this in TripleO but at this moment this change does not affect usage of TripleO so I don't see any blocker for it, unless Glance team is planning to abandon support for wsgi mechanism which is not true AFAIK.

I don't have time nor energy to get into the details now. I can get back to the conversation some point in August when I'm back from PTO. If your aim is to make this default in the downstream product, I'd advice to discuss it with the service team first, spoiler alert I don't see us supporting this for OSP.

While the bug you mentioned was the last hard cap why you couldn't deploy g-api on mod_wsgi it by no means was not the only reason why you shouldn't.

I agree that we can still implement this logic in Puppet OpenStack to keep consistency it's up to deployments (or deployment tools) to make a decision on how to run it, this should cause us any more churn that we already have on all other modules.

Hi Rodrigo,

Thanks for taking the time in documenting your investigation in the bug.

Something I'm not convinced on why/how config-changed is run before upgrade-charm, I have this other patch in the queue https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-mysql-router/+/848748 which addresses the fact we are not restarting mysql-router service after we made the changes to the configuration.

Actually, thinking about this further, it may not exacerbate/reintroduce the issue because config-changed would not have written the PID path to the config file, so the properties you are adding in the custom upgrade-path and subsequent restart may not cause the mysql-router service to be stuck in a failed state until the parent upgrade-charm runs to fix the PID change, but it would be extra restarts nonetheless. I guess moving "super(MySQLRouterCharm, self).upgrade_charm()" around to the top might not make a difference. This would need to be tested to know for sure.

Thanks for reviewing this patch Felipe. The config-changed hook is invoked at [4] from LP #1980693. It is clearly visible when you use TRACE level logging-config while performing upgrade-charm.

I have briefly looked at your other change, and I believe it would exacerbate and reintroduce the problem this change is addressing, because it would be attempting to restart mysql-router before the systemd update is done (which is by running "super(MySQLRouterCharm, self).upgrade_charm()"). To prevent reintroducing this problem, "super(MySQLRouterCharm, self).upgrade_charm()" would have to be run first in the custom upgrade_charm function. However, I believe doing so will cause extra restarts, as your new code will be restarting it again in the custom upgrade-charm function code, but it may still be the only functional solution.

This change (to my patch) would run super().upgrade_charm(), then we acommodate mysqlrouter.conf and at the end we restart mysql-router service, all in a single pass due to the context manager.

```
diff --git a/src/lib/charm/openstack/mysql_router.py b/src/lib/charm/openstack/mysql_router.py
index b70bde2..0f8d384 100644
--- a/src/lib/charm/openstack/mysql_router.py
+++ b/src/lib/charm/openstack/mysql_router.py
@@ -342,6 +342,8 @@ class MySQLRouterCharm(charms_openstack.charm.OpenStackCharm):
         with ch_core.host.restart_on_change(
                 self.restart_map,
                 restart_functions=self.restart_functions):
+            super(MySQLRouterCharm, self).upgrade_charm()
+
             # On upgrade set the unknown_config_option to warning
             # (LP: #1971565)
             if 'unknown_config_option' not in config[DEFAULT_SECTION]:
@@ -371,8 +373,6 @@ class MySQLRouterCharm(charms_openstack.charm.OpenStackCharm):
                 with open(self.mysqlrouter_conf, 'w') as configfile:
                     config.write(configfile)
 
-        super(MySQLRouterCharm, self).upgrade_charm()
-
     def get_db_helper(self):
         """Get an instance of the MySQLDB8Helper class.
 
```

Hello Felipe. I tested several variations of this, and I found that the change 848748 does not address the PID issue regardless of the parent upgrade-charm call being at the top or at the bottom of the custom upgrade-charm method.

I decided then to mix both this and your change together. The PID issue was addressed, but with multiple restarts. I decided then to improve on that by doing 2 things:

1) nesting self._config_changed(force_allow_restart=True) inside the "with restart_on_change" block.

2) adding a condition "if force_allow_restart:" in _config_changed to avoid doing another "with restart_on_change" when invoked by the custom upgrade-charm method.

I kept the parent upgrade-charm call at the top of the custom upgrade-charm method as I thought that was better.

The end result was only 1 restart of the service. I believe both changes should be combined or rebased on top of the other so the adjustments above can be made.

charm-recheck

> juju error?
> subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command '['config-get', '--all', '--format=json']' returned non-zero exit status 1.

[Broken Use Case]

This patch only prevents an error when MySQL is upgraded from <8.0.23 before charm upgrade. It still breaks if you upgrade the mysql-router package after upgrading the charm during the following test

(1) Deploy an old version of the mysql-router package with charm revision 4 (client_ssl_mode was added in revision 5)
(2) Upgrade the charm to this version
 (3) Upgrade mysql-router to the latest
(4) Restart the *-mysql-router service (package upgrade does not auto-restart the services)

As newer versions of MySQL break with older charm configuration files (due to the 'name' parameter not really existing and the lack of the 'unknown_config_option = warning' option, see Bug #1971565) this is also a likely upgrade path for people to take.

[Correct Fix]

In 8.0.23 when they added SSL support the bootstrap process now always creates a self signed SSL cert and the path is recorded in the client_ssl_cert path option, it then also writes the client_ssl_mode=PREFERRED to the configuration file by default. If you startup with client_ssl_mode=PREFERRED set and without client_ssl_cert set an error is thrown.

Hence the real cause of the problem is that the charm will *add* client_ssl_mode=PREFERRED to the configuration file in all cases even if the option didn't already exist, but this option is only valid when client_ssl_cert exists.

The simple and correct fix that also supports MySQL versions <8.0.23 is to ensure that the charm never writes ‘client_ssl_mode=PREFERRED’ to the configuration file unless ‘client_ssl_cert’ also already exists. Generally also it should only 'add' this option by doing the bootstrap process.

To additionally fix deployments already upgraded to the broken versions of the charm, it should probably also actively REMOVE the client_ssl_mode configuration option if the client_ssl_cert option does not exist and the MySQL version is <8.0.23. The code in lib/charm/openstack/mysql_router.py:MySQLRouterCharm#config_changed should be updated to enforce this requirement. 

This described change alone should prevent the original Bug from occurring and no re-bootstrap is needed.

[Additional Fix]
While the above described change would resolve the current bug, it would perhaps be ideal to oppurtunistically re-bootstrap to enable SSL in client_ssl_mode=PREFERRED to make it consistent with newer deployments.

Having said that, it seems that the ssl_ca relation data is only sent when we receive one from mysql-innodb-cluster. If we receive one, then we switch the charm to "PASSTHROUGH" mode and no client_ssl_cert is needed for that, since it simply proxies the SSL connection entirely to the server and does not need a local certificate.

So it seems SSL will likely not be consumed in a mandatory change by other charms in PREFERRED mode, as there is no other indication of whether SSL is supported or not. So we may not really gain anything, at least currently, by doing this re-bootstrap process.

If we do add one, we should ensure that client_ssl_cert is missing (as currently checked in the draft aptch) and mysql-router version is >= 8.0.23 (not currently checked).

The main risk of such a change is that a future MySQL version stops always writing the client_ssl_cert parameter in which case we may continually re-bootstrap the service. So it may make sense to have a flag for having attempted this and not repeat it? 

This kind of a change is not unexpected as Upstream MySQL 8.0 releaes are SRUd to -security (which gets unattended-upgrades treatment) and frequently makes breaking behaviour changes (e.g. Bug #1914299, Bug #1971565). 

[Conclusion]

For the purposes of a stable backport, it would likely be safer to implement the client_ssl_mode/client_ssl_cert logic fix described above only. If a re-bootstrap step is added (which I am not opposed to) it should be a separate review so that it does not have to be backported to stable immediately and can receive further testing.
In case somehow we upgrade mysql-router pkg first from 8.0.22 to 8.0.23 to 8.0.27, then upgrade charm. charm will add ssl configuration but no cert related files as no bootstrapped.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
:-1: The scenario is to delete a volume when its status is "backing up" using cinder cli? we need a bug created in launchpad, to have the reference added to this commit message.

I don't think we need a release note.

> I agree this warrants a launchpad bug, but that suggests to me that the fix *does* need a release note.

+1
I agree this warrants a launchpad bug, but that suggests to me that the fix *does* need a release note.
Done

I'm not sure I understand the bug report.  If an admin wants to delete a volume that's in use, that seems like a reasonable thing to do.  Why is this a bug?

This also doesn't consider the other ways that admins could stop this process: using reset-state then delete (which is likely what would be used after the limitation introduced by this patch is in place), using a force-detach, etc.

Does this patch really solve a problem?

What is the root issue being solved by this?  Would having the force-delete operation do a force detach also solve it?

There's a Red Hat bug [1], but unfortunately it's not publicly accessible so I'll summarize it here.

Cinder needs to restrict the ability to force-delete a volume when cinder itself is connected to the storage backend. This means you should not be able to force delete a cinder volume when it's in the 'downloading' or 'backing-up' states. Deleting the volume causes cinder to disconnect from the storage backend, and if there's a cinder-volume or cinder-backup thread trying to do I/O the process will get stuck in the "uninterruptible sleep" D state that can only be fixed by rebooting the node.

Active backups can be cancelled, and (presumably) it shouldn't take too long for cinder to finish downloading an image. Meanwhile, adding a restriction to prevent deleting a volume while 'downloading' or 'backing-up' will help avoid processes getting stuck in the 'D' state.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2079723

A volume attached to an instance is not allowed to be deleted even with the force flag by checking its attach status. However, a temporary volume for back-up or download, which is attached to a cinder service, can be deleted. This patch will introduce the similar restriction to deletion of a temporary volume.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'm beginning to wonder what those issues were, because now it seems we're just adding yet even more options when all we really want here is a URI override, sort of like what we do with config options to talk to cinder/neutron/glance/ironic endpoints. Wouldn't it almost be easier to just undeprecate live_migration_uri?

Nothing to do with oslo.config. It's the python % string formatting in nova that's the issue.

It's a uri, and we can have a urlencoded query string (e.g to set the ssh key). However we need to s/%/%%/g in the querystring to prevent a 'TypeError: not enough arguments for format string' exception.

We could fix this in nova, e.g use string.replace('%s', foobar) instead,  but this would be a breaking change for anyone that has already worked around the issue.

The new params allow us to use live_migration_scheme + live_migration_inbound_addr instead and deprecate this broken param.

The were LP bugs for this IIRC, I'll dig them up.

There are a couple of reasons that the 'live_migration_uri' option shouldn't be used and I wrote them down...somewhere :/ The only one I can think of now is that the the string it uses relies of printf string formatting (i.e. %s). However, because of how oslo.config works you need to double escape these strings. This has proven very confusing for people. There are other, more significant issues associated with it but I'm trying to find my notes on these
complement

It would be helpful to enumerate some of the issues with live_migration_uri. And also explain why we need all of the parts to configure to make the URI when one might think, "why can't I just configure nova to use a single live migration URI in the first place?". The answer is, only nova knows the destination host/ip during the live migration, which we have to substitute into the live_migration_uri, which is part of the problem when we don't have a good way to replace the other parts of the URI like credentials and query parameters. So we need something that handles string replacement for the host. This should be explained a bit in the commit message because this is a confusing set of options to be dealing with so we should know what we're fixing, and how and why.

Please update this bit, as it is no longer true—we've recently removed[*] usage of the older migrateToURI{2}() APIs, and added the migrateToURI3(), as Nova's minimum libvirt version satisfies the requirement.

[*] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/commit/?id=4b3e877

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: I am not quite sure here, but my understanding is that username, port and extra_parameters (at least some of them) are only relevant in the case of "kvm" or "qemu" driver and when "ssh" is used. if thats the case, these options should only be appended to the uri in those scenarios. meanwhile, we can also make it clear that only certain combinations of these options will work as expected in the configuration file.

If we were to add checks here, we'd be (a) duplicating what libvirt is already doing and (b) setting us up for failure if/when libvirt introduced another type of driver/schema.
Note to self: this is specifically for turning dicts (or lists of 2-tuples) into URL query params.

i am pretty sure you are not required to url encode all the query parmaters, just the ones the libvirt does not support directly. if people are url encoding them which woudl generate % then that is likely the cause of the bugs that people are having. its a URI not a URL they are different things and uri do not always use/require or support url encoding.

https://libvirt.org/uri.html#Remote_URI_parameters

https://libvirt.org/uri.html states RFC 2396.

TL;DR not different things (URLs are URIs) and always encode reserved characters (which includes '/'). URI parser implementations might be more forgiving though.

doc/source/job-content.rst.message:
A more accurate description would be:

The relative priority of this queue item's node requests compared to other items in the same pipeline in the same tenant at the time the build request for this job was enqueued (though the value here does not reflect whether this tenant actually has the relative_priority feature enabled).

releasenotes/notes/node_priority-ffa7f9b.message:
This is using the relative priority calculation, but it uses it regardless of whether or not relative priority is enabled for a tenant, so it won't match what we pass to Nodepool.  That may be a little counter-intuitive for some folks.

Also, since it's intended for use by Nodepool it has some intentional optimizations that shouldn't make a difference for that use case but could be confusing; it quantizes the values at certain levels.

The number is intended to change frequently until Nodepool actually allocates a node.  The fact that it's frozen in place when the build is enqueued means it won't work the same way in a build.  Imagine a job that happens to start with a very low priority.  Circumstances change and it's at the top of the queue now.  But other items right behind it start and they actually have a higher priority.  In short, I think it's potentially dangerous to use this in a job, and I think it should be limited and retained for its intended use as an internal value.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The operator is only constrained to use an extra vars file when they have to pass complex data structure like a dict for instance. For simple key=value, they can use --extra-vars with commas (with your patch) and/or using multiple --extra-vars args if they prefer.

This sentence should be rephrase IMO.
Done

This is not true, the CLI works like Ansible does:
validation run --validation check-ram --extra-vars foo=bar --extra-vars bar=foo

Then you will have:
extras_vars -> {'bar': 'foo', 'foo': 'bar'}

Those parameters was made to be "compliant" with ansible cli, so the user wont have different behaviours with those params.

> This is not true, the CLI works like Ansible does:
> validation run --validation check-ram --extra-vars foo=bar --extra-vars bar=foo
> 
> Then you will have:
> extras_vars -> {'bar': 'foo', 'foo': 'bar'}
> 
> Those parameters was made to be "compliant" with ansible cli, so the user wont have different behaviours with those params.

Well, I agree with what Mathieu says here about the ansible CLI compliance and behavior mimicking. We are good here.

But, the current CLI for 16.[1|2] in tripleoclient is allowing this way to pass extra variables (it actually uses the MultiKeyActionValue parser action coming from osc_lib):

  --extra-vars minimal_ram_gb=1,minimal_count_cpu=1 --extra-vars minimal_ram_gb=19

Which gives us:
  
  parsed_args.extra_vars -> {'minimal_ram_gb': '19', 'minimal_count_cpu': '1'}

This is not allowed anymore since we introduce the new Validation CLI. If you want to pass multiple KEY=VALUE, you have to use --extra-vars as much as you have vars to pass. The value override is still compliant in both ways.

Now the question is: 

Do we want to be iso-functional here?
Done

Imho, we should stick with the behavior from the tripleoclient.
It's what most of our customers are familiar with, after all the VF CLI is very recent addition.

On the other hand, we are wrappng around ansible, so there is an argument for harmony in the args.

Still, I can't help but feel that supplying one argument and multiple key=>val pairs, separated by comma, is easier than multiple args with one key=>val each.

specs/yoga/approved/ovn-central-downscal.message:
I really like this detail of the specification, however it is unclear to me from reading this whether the cluster/kick action needs to be performed to a specific member of the cluster (such as the leader) or all of them.

The proposal to make this action driven by the operator or some other higher entity is a good one, but if it turns out it needs to be executed on all of the remaining units, should that concerted effort be executed by the charms on behalf of the action executor?

If it turns out it needs to be executed on the leader only, should that be recorded in the spec so that the action only executes on the leader, with an appropriate message given to the end user in the event they try to execute it on a non-leader unit?

Thanks for the review Frode. You are right, I did not make this explicitly clear but there is no specific requirement on which unit the "kick" action must executed. It can be executed on any unit that's still active participant in the OVN cluster and it needs to be done only once.

I'll update the spec to make this clear.

specs/version1.2/amphora-vertical-scalin.message: We need to disable irq_balance or create a custom profile for it.

I would argue this is no longer true.
There are also proposals to remove the multi-process (nbproc) option from HAProxy completely.
I don't think tuned has an haproxy profile, but this can be done directly in the haproxy configuration file via the amphora agent.
What I meant here is that TuneD would be used to prevent other processes/threads from using the vCPUs that are mapped to HAProxy (not sure if HAProxy should use them exclusively).

I think we want to setup tuned in a diskimage-builder element. This way the proper services will start and load the profile at boot time.
However, it might be a good idea to have a configuration setting for the CPU pinning that can be overridden in a flavor.
FYI, the "tuna" tool may be helpful here to simplify pinning the NIC interrupts. It is available on both Red Hat and Ubuntu.

zuul/scheduler.py.message:
Should we maybe update the `last_reconfigure_event_ltime` after we've triggered the tenant reconfig?

Just thinking about what happens when something goes wrong during sending of the trigger event. I think the trigger event processing would be stuck and needs to be fixed by a full tenant reconfiguration to create a new layout state.
Do we need any sort of delay here to prevent us from immedaitely trying to process the pipeline trigger queue potentially starving the reconfiguration work that will allow us to proceed?

We will go back to the loop where we iterate over every pipeline in the tenant.  If we are the only scheduler, then we will process that pipeline up to the event time and reach this same point and return early; we'll eventually get to the point where we finish the tenant and process the tenant reconfig event.

If we're in a multi-scheduler system, then in the best case, another scheduler is sitting on that reconfig event right now and trying to get the tenant write lock.  There's a special short-circuit in the pipeline loop that will exit early if someone's waiting to reconfigure the tenant.  So we'll stop processing the rest of the tenant very quickly and let that other scheduler proceed.

If we're in a multi-scheduler system and another scheduler hasn't gotten around to that event yet, we'll behave like the first case until it does, then we'll behave like the second.

That's what I like most about this change -- it preserves the parallelism as much as possible until it really needs to stop and do the reconfiguration.
